review_title: What Happened to the once respected college
pros: Helping students succeed Caring employees Benefits
cons: Controlling upper management that don't know what they are doing Terrible support from incompetent CCIT department - the "instructional designers" there to assist the SME in designing courses. You, as the SME (instructor) are to do their job as well as yours. Upper management does not care you are teaching full-time. They expect you to rebuild an entire curriculum on your "spare time" Once upon a time, or 1st question was "Is this the best thing for the student?" Now its "what about our image" which has been greatly damaged. Word on the streets is Delaware Tech went way down hill.

job_title: Part Time Counselor in Wilmington, DE
pros: Nice work environment and students are friendly.
cons: It can take years to get a full time position.

review_title: Used to be the best job in the world....
pros: Working with the students. Lots of PTO
cons: Faculty have no voice. Administration dictates classroom and course management requirements and policies without soliciting faculty input. Punitive leadership style. Very toxic work environment. A union is badly needed, but everyone is scared to organize.

pros: Student oriented, friendly work environment, great benefits

pros: 1) Helping people to succeed 2) Young adults full-of-life 3) Learning environments are usually positive  3)  rewarding 4) always learning something new 5) camaraderie  6) family is important and respected
cons: 1) VERY difficult to make change 2) stuck in old ways of doing things 3) more about their image than the student (like it used to be).  4) Not enough budget 5) outdated CMS  6) online classes are not approved and some are built badly 7) professional development is not easy to get approved  8) some employees get special treatment - all employees are not treated the same or required to live by the same rules.  9) not very progressive  10)  waste money paying department chairs to do administrative work

review_title: Too many incompetent administrators who should not be retained as they are under performers.
pros: State job, benefits, small pension.
cons: Leadership is arrogant and incompetent. Faculty and administrators get raises every year just for being here taking up space and for lane changes. Salary B positions never have the opportunity to increase their income except for the few 1% State approved raises. Definitely not a good career place for Salary B and C employees. Also, if your supervisor is incompetent and a jerk (or a sociopath), the management will NEVER remove that person. If you complain, then your life will become a living hell and you will be run out. They rarely "fire" people (unless you steal) but they will torture you and write you up until your health fails and you can't take it any more and then you leave. I've seen the BEST people run out so that many of the people who remain, are the ones who should be fired. Not a good career prospect if you would be Salary B. Save yourself and look somewhere else for a really good job where the leadership is at least fair. You won't find that here.

review_title: Very political environment, but the staff is nice.
job_title: Teaching Resource Center Technician in Georgetown, DE
pros: My co-workers were very nice and interesting people.  We worked together well as a team.  The insurance was good because you get it through the State of Delaware.
cons: The pay was not good at all for the amount of work they have you doing.  The management leaves a lot to be desired because they promote people who have education degrees and not people who have education and/or skills in managing people and departments.  People are promoted based of how many people they have successfully shmoozed and not on their talents.

pros:
- There are a few instructors that really truly care about their students.
- People are are relatively friendly.
- Job provides good opportunity to move around departments and move up a pay-scale or two.
- Fantastic benefits and time off

It can be a super comfortable state job if the cons don't bother you.
cons:
- Higher management will pick favorites, and they also reward hard work with more work. 
- The company will focus more on purchasing "new" things instead of fixing or updating what they currently have. 
- The technology provided for employees and students to use is mostly outdated and worthless.
- Del Tech hire/promote individuals that really don't know the trade of the position they're in (see first point). 
- The interview process is outdated (some questions asked that did not relate to the job and would have only been relevant a decade ago).

pros: This is a good part-time job as it has a variety of class times available to fit almost any desired schedule.
cons: The college recently cut the academic calendar from 16 weeks to 15 weeks, and has increased the number of seats available in each course. The adjuncts are receiving less pay and spending many additional (unpaid) hours grading more papers per course with the addition of 5-7 students per class. The college also eliminated paid "adjunct engagement hours", which allowed additional time outside the classroom for one on one tutoring. Student success has been impacted by the elimination of this program.

pros:
Our students don't come from privileged backgrounds. This is an institution where you can make a real difference in the lives of our students. We are mentors, friends, advisors, counselors, teachers, and more. 
Great faculty. The values that shape the institution are on target.
cons: Too much work. Designing my courses and managing those courses in our LMS takes up the majority of my time. Lesson plans and grading are done at home or late hours on campus. Large class sizes (too large) and no opportunity for input in major decisions that affect instruction and students. Pay is 2-4% less than our counterparts elsewhere.

job_title: Computing Support Specialist II in Wilmington, DE
pros: Good benefits, fair hours, state job and nice co workers/ employees. Helping the staff here was the highlight of the job
cons: Too political and garbage management. If you like being micro managed by someone who has love skill sets than you then this is the place. Lots of family and friends get hired here rather than qualified applicants.

pros:
Delaware Tech has a great culture full of people passionate about student success. 
The benefits are state benefits plus college benefits and are worth staying for lower pay.
Instructors get good raises and education based bonuses
The management is flexible with schedules and are implementing telecommuting and other flex type schedules
cons:
The pay is lower than state pay in many cases, especially for non-faculty employees
Non-faculty never get raises, so you are stuck at whatever you started out unless a spot opens that pays more

pros: Competitive wage. Set hours. Attractive building. Nice coworkers.
cons: An unfair and sometimes cruel and subtly abusive ranking of positions.  Confining job descriptions with abundant rules that under- utilize and prohibit employee growth. Deceptive promises for advancement that do not exist to recruit employees to recover quickly from turnover. Promotions predetermined by the elect bureaucracy doing the hiring.

pros: Vacation time and benifits are good.  Staff are mostly nice and everyone cares about the students and creating a good learning environment
cons: Short staffed, so most staff are over worked.  Very hierarchical environment, with poor communication.

pros:
Great staff!
Any chance to assist with the careers of students is what its all about!

pros: The number 1 reason is that you get one class paid in full, when you work there. That alone is an excellent reason to work there part-time.
cons: Can be time consuming, when juggling work life and school life. Just have to manage your time wisely.

pros: The interaction with the students. Everyday I get to encourage a student to fulfill their dreams.
